Title: The Evolutionary Origins of Friendship: A Cross-Species Comparison and Experimental Approach

This project aims to investigate the evolutionary origins of friendship, a crucial aspect of human health and well-being, with significant implications for public health and political policy. Social isolation, a growing concern, is linked to increased risks of heart disease and other negative outcomes, comparable to those associated with heavy smoking, excessive drinking, and obesity. To address this issue, our research will employ a cross-species comparison and experimental approach to explore the evolutionary roots of friendship.

Focusing on nonhuman primates, specifically macaques, we will create a comprehensive dataset to investigate the environmental forces driving variation in social bonds across species. We will also conduct social experiments to establish whether humans possess a unique ability to gather information about the friendships of unrelated others. Furthermore, we will test the hypothesis that social isolation results from competitive exclusion.

Our research has three primary aims: (1) to identify the environmental forces shaping social bonds across species, (2) to determine whether humans possess a unique ability to understand the friendships of others, and (3) to investigate the role of competitive exclusion in social isolation. By achieving these aims, we will gain a deeper understanding of the evolutionary perspective on friendship, ultimately informing strategies to mitigate social isolation and promote healthy relationships.
